metadata.title: Seroepidemiology of group I human coronaviruses in children

abstract.original_text: Background-Recently, several new human coronaviruses have been identified.

sentences.segment_text: Background-Recently , several new human coronaviruses have been identified .

abstract.original_text: Study design-A recombinant protein enzyme linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) based on portions of the nucleocapsid protein of group I human coronaviruses was developed and was used to screen serum from 243 children and young adults.

sentences.segment_text: Study design-A recombinant protein enzyme linked immunosorbent assay ( ELISA ) based on portions of the nucleocapsid protein of group I human coronaviruses was developed and was used to screen serum from 243 children and young adults .

abstract.original_text: HCoV-229E, the percentages of seropositive individuals were 57.1% for infants < 2 months old; 38.9% for infants 2-3 months old; 4.7% for infants 4-5 months old; 42.9-50.0% for infants 6-12 months old; and 34.8-62.5% for individuals 1-20 years old. For HCoV-NL63, the percentages of seropositive individuals were 45.2% for infants < 2 months old; 11.1% for infants 2-3 months old; 4.7% for infants 4-5 months old; 28.6-40.0% for infants 6-12 months old; and 25.0-70.3% for individuals 1-20 years old.

sentences.segment_text: HCoV-229E , the percentages of seropositive individuals were 57.1 % for infants < 2 months old ; 38.9 % for infants 2-3 months old ; 4.7 % for infants 4-5 months old ; 42.9-50.0 % for infants 6-12 months old ; and 34.8-62.5 % for individuals 1-20 years old .

For HCoV-NL63 , the percentages of seropositive individuals were 45.2 % for infants < 2 months old ; 11.1 % for infants 2-3 months old ; 4.7 % for infants 4-5 months old ; 28.6-40.0 % for infants 6-12 months old ; and 25.0-70.3 % for individuals 1-20 years old .

abstract.original_text: Conclusions-Infection with these viruses is common in childhood though the prevalence of these viruses may vary from year to year.

sentences.segment_text: Conclusions-Infection with these viruses is common in childhood though the prevalence of these viruses may vary from year to year .
